attributes.title: Physical Stock Take
attributes.description:
·       A physical inventory count was carried out on April 28 2025, to verify the accuracy of stock records by matching actual inventory quantities against the figures recorded in the SAP system. Additionally, the count served to assess the effectiveness of internal controls over inventory management.

·       The physical stock count revealed the following discrepancies:

Ø  Bread stock showed a surplus of 24 Loaves,

Ø  Packing material had  a surplus of 293 pieces,

Ø  White flour had a surplus of +22.47kgs,

Ø  Wheat bran had had  a Surplus of 1.00kgs,

Ø  Other material items had minimal variances.

The table below illustrates the findings:

Implications:

·       The 22.47 kg surplus of white flour identified during the physical stock count suggests potential inefficiencies or irregularities in the production recording and material usage processes. The discrepancy could point to deeper operational or control issues such as:

Ø  Inconsistent Yield Performance between Units: The surplus may reflect periods where one or both units failed to attain their expected yields. Lower-than-expected flour consumption without a corresponding drop in output could mean yield targets were not met leading to an artificial accumulation of raw materials

Ø  Misalignment or Manipulation in Recording; the excess flour could also arise from inaccurate or manipulated entries in the records. This may involve overstating output to meet performance metrics or even dough weight inconsistencies.

Overall, the observed variances in other stock items may point to underlying weaknesses in the branch’s inventory control systems and monitoring practices
attributes.recommendation:
·         Branch management should conduct a thorough review of the yield reporting for both production units, ensuring that each unit’s output is correctly recorded.

·         The branch management should also introduce tighter oversight for frequently mismatched items in order to reduce the variances noted to low levels.

value:
·       We will review the yield recording process due to the differences observed between the two units, which operate under separate BOMs.

·       The issue primarily came from discrepancies in recording and system posting.

We will enhance our planning and documentation processes while maintaining the effectiveness of other existing controls

·       It seems the stock and RM is under control

Apart from two different yield in both unit which is challenges but it’s upon the clerk and manager proper posting in the sap to avoid the variation.

·       In the prior Audit, dated 19th March 2025,the following variances were noted:

ü  Bread stock had a shortfall of -48 Pieces,

ü  Polybags had +865 pieces,

ü  White flour had -0.83 Kgs,

ü  Crates surplus of one crate

Other stock items had minimal variances.
Previous

attributes.title: Bread Weights
attributes.description:
·       A spot check on 30 April 2025 assessed the weight of packed bread before dispatch to ensure compliance with weight standards.

·       The findings revealed inconsistencies across different bread varieties, with cases of underweight, overweight and correctly weighted bread recorded.

Ø  Incidence of Underweight Bread: Several bread varieties, particularly the 800g BW and 200g ML, recorded notable percentages of underweight samples.

Ø  Overweight Bread: All bread varieties except for the 800g barrel bread, showed a significant number of overweight units suggesting possible overconsumption of raw materials and resulting cost inefficiencies.

Implications:

·       The presence of underweight bread in the market potentially subject the company to fines, penalties, or legal action from regulatory bodies.

·       Delivering underweight products can result in customer dissatisfaction, damaging the brand’s reputation and potentially leading to loss of market share.

Overweight bread could increase costs per unit, affecting profitability without necessarily increasing revenue.
attributes.recommendation: ·       The branch is recommended to maintain and regularly review existing weight control mechanisms during dough making and slicing to ensure consistent compliance with defined weight standards for all bread varieties.

value:
·       Overcooling was observed in the 800g barrel bread and miniloaf varieties due to insufficient manpower. To address this additional employees has been assigned and will report on the following day.

·       With adequate staffing, we aim to reduce overcooling.

·       We will continue to monitor overweight issues by ensuring adherence to the designated dividing range.

Frequent spot checks will be conducted to maintain consistency and ensure overall compliance.

·       We shall work on it to avoid underweight which is observed specially in 800Gm Barrel and mini loaf

·       Its indicating overcooling because its never been packed on time

·       Advice to the manager to avoid such issue further.

Other varieties were ok

·       In the prior audit dated 19th March 2025, it was noted that Underweights in packed breads were as follows;    

ü  400g CTW -23%,

ü  400Grand-42%,

ü  600g Bw-77%,

ü  600g CTW-13%,

ü  800 CTW-17%,

ü  400g S/N-7%,

attributes.title: Bread damages Percentage Analysis
attributes.description:
·       We reviewed the damages for the period from 29 March 2025, to 28 April 2025 to assess whether there were any instances of damages exceeding the established standard limits of 0.2% of total production for production-related damages and 0.5% of total sales for market-related damages.

·       Production damages accounted for 0.24% of total production, exceeding the standard limit by 0.04%, with a cost implication of Ksh 21,703.71

·       Market damages reached 0.44% of total sales, below the allowable limit of 0.5%

·       The findings were as detailed below:

NB: This analysis was exclusive of 650 pcs of oven damages.

Damages sent to Ingredients’ Balance Analysis

·       A verification exercise was undertaken for the period 29 March to 28 April 2025 to confirm whether all reported bread damages were either physically present or correctly transferred to the ingredient department as per established procedures.

·       The analysis revealed a variance of 12.11 kg, which translates to 30.28 loaves and a cost implication of Kshs. 1,604.58. This suggests that actual physical damages at the branch exceeded the amounts recorded in both the system and the book record as detailed below:

Implications

·       Overage in production damages indicates inefficiencies in the production process, leading to avoidable wastage and cost escalation.

·       Rise in production damages could indirectly affect product quality consistency, which may, over time, impact customer satisfaction.

The variance of the damages sent to ingredient indicates discrepancies between reported and actual bread damages. This suggests that not all physical damages were properly recorded or transferred to the ingredients department as per procedure.
attributes.recommendation:
·       Branch management should implement and enforce a preventive maintenance program for key production equipment particularly ovens to reduce the frequency of unplanned breakdowns.

·       Branch management should also introduce damage performance checklist to monitor trends, track recurring issues and assess the effectiveness of interventions in real-time.

Branch management should also strengthen the enforcement of current procedures to ensure that all daily damages are weighed and verified before being sent to the ingredients department, guaranteeing that accurate values are recorded and the status of both declared and available damages is accurately reflected.

value:
·       The excessive production damage was caused by frequent oven breakdowns, particularly during night shifts.

·       Repairs have been slow at night and we recommend assigning a night technician to address the issue more promptly.

·       A service ticket has always been raised on time.

·       Controls at the branch for managing market damages are effective.

However, efforts will be made to further improve bread quality to reduce these damages even more

·       We shall control the production damages by implementing preventive maintenance work

·       Excess damages here cause by the excess tins rotation and over proofing which needs to avoid by the manager by giving proper training to the CHB

·       Market damages are under control

·       During the prior audit dated 19th March 2025, it was found that;        

ü  Production bread damages were averaging at 0.25% of the production.

Market damages stood at 0.45% of the sales.
Previous

attributes.title: Mixing Chart Analysis
attributes.description:
·       An analysis of the mixing charts and summaries was conducted over a 31-day period, 29 March 2025 to 28 April 2025 to evaluate whether raw material usage aligned with the established BOM and if production standards were met. The goal of this review was to examine both shift-wise and summarized mixing chart documents, with a particular focus on the branch's Utto oil consumption, average yield and instances of remixes, as outlined below.

·       Below are summary of the findings:

ü  Utto consumption stood at 100%.

ü  Average yield was 191.57 loaves per bag.

ü  Average production was 172.39 bags per day representing 72.43% of the set target of 238 bags.

ü  There were 981 cases of remixes for the reviewed period.

·       The table below shows a summarised findings of the mixing chart analysis.

Implications:

·       Un-attainment of production targets indicates inefficiencies in planning, equipment availability and labour utilization.

·       The occurrence of remixes as noted can result in increased labour cost, energy costs and potential quality issues.

Frequent oven breakdowns and initial issues with the mixer directly can interfere with production continuity
attributes.recommendation:
·       Branch management should strengthen and strictly implement a preventive maintenance schedule for key production machinery especially ovens and mixers to minimize unplanned downtime and improve overall equipment reliability.

A formal request should be made to assign a night technician ensuring the branch has consistent and reliable repair support during all shifts in the event of equipment breakdowns.

value:
·       During the period under review we experienced frequent breakdowns of the oven machine.

·        The mixer also had issues although those were resolved.

However, delays in oven repairs affected production and as a result we were unable to meet the target.

·       Target were not achieved due to the low sales and less manpower

·       However the management is planning to hire new employees to be trained to get maximum production target to be achieved.

·       We shall plan for the preventive maintenance schedule for the mixer and oven.

·       In the prior audit, it was noted that;

ü  Average yield was at 191.15 loaves per bag,

ü  Utto consumption was at 100%,

ü  Average production was at 162.24 bags per day representing 70.54% of the set target of 230 bags.
Previous

attributes.title: Production Efficiency
attributes.description:
·       Production efficiency was evaluated over a 31-day period from 29 March 2025 to 28 April 2025 to determine whether hired production workers met the set efficiency target of 4.50 bags per worker.

·       The actual efficiency achieved was 4.15 bags per worker, falling short of the target.

·       The branch hired 1,287 production workers, whereas only 1,188 were needed based on actual output, resulting in 99 excess workers.

·       This overstaffing led to an additional cost of Ksh 107,573.40 for the period.

·       Frequent machine breakdowns and unresolved power supply limitations also contributed to reduced worker utilization and production inefficiencies.

·       A summary of the analysis is shown below;

Implications:

·       Falling short of the efficiency target suggests that labour resources were not optimally utilized, leading to increased operational costs without proportional output.

·       Hiring beyond the required number of workers resulted in avoidable labour expenses, directly affecting profitability.

Frequent equipment failures and ongoing power limitations hindered continuous production further contributing to inefficiency.
attributes.recommendation: ·       Branch management should regularly review and adjust staffing levels based on accurate production forecasts and efficiency performance to avoid overstaffing and unnecessary labour costs.

value:
·       Frequent machine breakdowns also impacted labor efficiency as production workers could not be fully utilized during downtime leading to reduced overall productivity.

·       Additionally, we experienced electricity supply issues, our generator could not support three ovens limiting production capacity.

This issue remains unresolved.

·       Breakdown of mixer and oven which affect the production target

But we shall work on it to get the production yield according to the company standard.

·       In the prior audit;

Production efficiency was 4.24 Bags per production worker.
Previous

attributes.title: Packing Efficiency
attributes.description:
·       The efficiency of human resource allocation in the packing area was evaluated by measuring packing efficiency over a 31-day period, from 29 March 2025 to 28 April 2025.

·       The assessment aimed to determine whether the company’s standard of 97 crates per slicer was being met.

·       The actual slicing efficiency recorded was 85.34 crates per slicer, which fell below the target of 97 crates per slicer.

·       88 additional packers were hired beyond the required number, resulting in an extra cost of Ksh 81,168.

·       Contributing factors to this underperformance included frequent breakdowns of the slicing machine, issues with the coding machine and delayed technician response times.

·       The table below illustrates the findings;-

Implications:

·       Hiring 89 more packers than necessary resulted in unnecessary expenditure, which could have been avoided with better resource planning.

The current gaps suggest room for improvement in aligning manpower deployment with actual production capacity and maintaining critical equipment
attributes.recommendation: Branch management should improve manpower planning methods to ensure staffing levels are accurately matched to anticipated packing requirements minimizing overstaffing and associated costs.

value:
·       The slicing machine experienced prolonged downtime for some days and the coding machine also encountered operational issues.

·       Additionally, there was a slow response time from the technician.

We are confident that the production targets can be achieved with adequate manpower and fully functional machinery.

·       The slicing machine experienced prolonged downtime for some days and the coding machine also encountered operational issues.

·       Additionally, there was a slow response time from the technician.

·       We shall work on it to get the packing efficiency according to the company standard
In the prior audit, the finding revealed that the average slicing efficiency was 85.77 crates per slicer.
Previous

attributes.title: Generator Fuel Consumption Analysis
attributes.description:
·       We conducted an analysis of the generator’s fuel consumption rate as at 30 April 2025 to determine if the Consumption rate was within the set standards.

·       We noted that the Fuel consumption rate for unit two for the period 30 April was 4.59Litres/Hour as per tracker system as detailed below while at the book records consumption rate stood at 8.66 Litres/Hour.

·       For unit one, the generator was having technical issue in regard to fuel refilling and mileage reading and the issue was considered for repair and calibration.

·       The table below illustrates fuel consumption for unit two generator.

Implications:

The fuel consumption was within the range however calibration is necessary for reconciliation purposes.
attributes.recommendation: Calibration of both generator units particularly Unit One which has reported technical issues with fuel refilling and mileage readings is necessary to ensure accurate tracking and alignment between physical usage and system records.

value: The generator's consumption was within the set standards.
The generator's consumption was within the set standards.
In the prior audit, the findings revealed that the consumption rate stood for unit one generator was at 18 litres per hour for unit one and 21.37 litres per hour for unit two
Previous

attributes.title: Mileage Analysis
attributes.description:
·       The audit aimed to evaluate the fuel consumption of the branch's sales vehicles for the period from 1 April to 28 April 2025.

·       The primary objectives were to assess compliance with fuel efficiency standards, identify any inefficiencies and propose recommendations to optimize fuel usage and reduce associated costs.

Findings revealed that fuel consumption at the branch generally adhered to the set standards. However few vehicles had over consumed fuel as detailed below.
attributes.recommendation: Branch management should maintain the controls in place and improve further where necessary.

value: We will continue to allocate fuel to vehicles based on the kilometres covered to ensure efficient and accountable fuel usage.
We will continue to allocate fuel to vehicles based on the kilometres covered to ensure efficient and accountable fuel usage.
In the prior audit, it was noted all routes were compliant with standard consumption.
Previous

attributes.title: Cash Verification
attributes.description:
·       A spot check was conducted in the cash office to verify that the physical cash on hand aligned with the cash flow records and to evaluate the effectiveness of existing cash control procedures.

·       All cash was properly accounted for, as outlined below:

Implications:

·       The close alignment between the calculated and actual cash balances indicates that current cash handling and reconciliation procedures are functioning effectively.

The small final variance of Ksh 11 though immaterial suggests a need for continued diligence in handling outstanding amounts such as uncollected funds
attributes.recommendation: Cashier should continue applying current cash management and reconciliation practices which have proven to be effective in ensuring financial accuracy.

value: ·       Cash controls are effective, and we will continue to maintain them.
Cash controls are effective, and we will continue to maintain them

attributes.title: Debtors’ Analysis
attributes.description:
·       An analysis of the debt balance as at 29 April 2025 was performed to identify any occurrences of bad debts or unresolved balances by route.

·       The analysis focused on dormant unsecured accounts and clients who had balances and therefore were not supplied as detailed below:

Implications:

·       If unsecured balances remain unpaid, they could negatively impact liquidity and operational efficiency.
attributes.recommendation: Sales representative is encouraged to actively follow up on overdue balances, particularly unsecured debts, to prevent them from becoming bad debts.

value: Sales team are following all outs standing debts.
We will follow-up with the sales team on outstanding balances
Routes balance as at the opening of 17th March 2025 were analyzed and the findings revealed that the total routes balance amounted to ksh. 734,686.34 including schools and hospitals
